lines.text: Your name?
Brown.
You sure it isn't Smith, or Jones?
[the contents of Father Brown's pockets are being inventoried by the police]
One Bible.

[Correcting the patrolman]
One breviary.
One... book.
One bar of milk chocolate.
One bar... of chocolate. Your glasses, please.
Oh. Is that really necessary? I'm as blind as a bat without them. Though I often wonder whether all bats are really blind, any more than all lords drunk or all judges sober.
I've never been in a cell before. Except a monastery cell, of course.
Father! You in trouble, Father?
I'm disappointed in you, Bert.
I'm sorry, Father, it was just...
Firstly, because you did wrong. Secondly, because you did wrong in the wrong way. Frankly, you are an incompetent thief.
Well, I wouldn't go that far.
I would. You are clearly incapable of earning a dishonest living. Why not experiment with an honest one?

Perhaps you think a crime horrible because you cannot imagine yourselves committing it. That isn't true, you know. What really horrifies you is the secret and shameful knowledge that you are capable of committing it. We all are, I no less than you. We were not made good people or bad people. We were made people.

[referring to the cross of St. Augustine]
It's very beautiful. Is it valuable?
No, not valuable. Priceless.

Where would a wise man hide a leaf? In a forest. Where would a wise man hide a cross? In a forest of crosses. We have a forest of crosses ready-made for us. A forest of priests; a black forest, you might say.
My lord, this is lunacy.

Father Brown, you will be good enough to leave matters in the lunatic hands of the inspector and myself. Scotland Yard will continue to inform you of our further insane decisions. Meanwhile, good morning.

[referring to smoking]
Disgusting habit!
But a very useful one sometimes. A friend of mine, Captain Chavasse of the Foreign Legion, leg half shot off. No anesthetic. Smoked a pipe all through the operation. Never felt a thing.
Good lord. What was he smoking?
Opium.
A simple but effective ruse, taught me by one of the lambs in my flock.
A strange flock.
Oh, not strange, just human. Albert was a dear fellow. Where do you think he is now?
In prison.
In a monastery. Life is full of surprises, isn't it?
One never dreams how full.

[after failing to commandeer a taxi with a couple kissing in the back]
Don't the police in France come before a pair of lovers?
In Paris, on a warm afternoon? I'm afraid not.
What progress have you made?
Looking for a black cat in a coal hole during an eclipse of the sun would be a child's task compared with mine.
"As I was walking up the stair, I met a man who wasn't there. He wasn't there again today. I wish that he would go away."
I wish that he would come to stay.
You'd've made things much easier for us both if you'd told us what you know of Flambeau.
I cannot tell you what I do not know. All I know is that he walks upon two legs and his head grows above his shoulders.

[the Texan approaches Father Brown and Lady Warren as they attempt to spot Flambeau among the bidders]
Lady Warren? I am Sam Johnson out of San Antonio, Texas. If isn't often we from Texas get a chance to shake a real, live lady by the hand now!
It isn't often that we in London have the privilege of of meeting a real, live Texan.
You sure talk like a lady. You know, I've come five thousand miles to buy this set of yours. It'll go well down on my ranch.
Will it really?
Yeah ma'am. I've got myself a real swell games room. Solid gold poker chips, solid gold checkers, and a solid gold ping pong table.
With solid gold ping pong balls?
No ma'am. They wouldn't bounce. Well, better get set to rope this steer.
[He goes to his seat]
I feared for a moment he was going to take my hand back to Texas with him, even though it isn't made of gold.
I doubt if even Flambeau could have invented him.
Now, who will open the bidding for me at ten thousand pounds?
Fifty thousand dollars.
I am bid... seventeen thousand, eight hundred and fifty-seven pounds, two shillings and ten pence. I think it would be easier, sir, if we were to conduct the bidding in pounds sterling.
Pardon, me lady, but the awful people are coming up the drive!
What awful people? It is not my "at home" day.
I think he means the police.

[the inspector has just phoned in an all-points bulletin for a stolen milk truck]
Your accomplices haven't got a chance. They'll be intercepted within half an hour.
Half an hour? Then you've time for a glass of sherry.
No thank you.
Or perhaps a glass of milk? The milkman seems to have left rather a lot today.
My son...
Please do not call me your son.

My son, you think that you are a man of the world and that I am not. But I assure you, my "innocent" ears encounter every day stories of a horror that would make your sophisticated hair stand on end. Although I wear funny clothes, and have taken certain vows, I live far more in the world than you do.
What are you really after, your cross or my soul?
Both, of course.
whatever you can find you shall have.
I accept your bargain.
It would have been an interesting encounter. Pity it will never take place.
Excuse me. Do you speak English?
Sure.
Have you noticed the river has started flowing backwards?
If you hadn't told me I never would have noticed.

And that the sun is moving from west to east. And that those trees, instead of growing, are shrinking down into the ground. All of which suggests to me that the course of history has started to unwind, and that we are approaching the end of the world.
In that case, I'd better be going. Thanks for the tip.
Well?
He is going to the wine harvest, and the grape waits for no man.
Nor does Father Brown.
It's all so nonsensical, it must make sense.
Appalling.
An odd word to apply to the finest private collection in the world.
What is appalling is that it is private.
You are the first person to have the privilege of seeing it. Look at my El Greco.
Yours?
Mine.
This, I believe, is yours.
[He hands Flambeau his cigarette case]
Oh. So that's how you traced me. Thank you. I wondered where I'd lost it.
You didn't lose it. I stole it.
We have something in common then.
All men do.
The police have an unfortunate habit of interrupting our conversations just when they begin to be interesting. I must beg your leave to leave you.
[Flambeau, while looking at "his" El Greco, overhears two young boys seeing it for the first time]
C'est joli, n'est-ce pas?
[It's pretty, isn't it?]
Oui, c'est tres beau.
[Yes, it's very beautiful]
The only visible door leads to nowhere. There must be an invisible door leading somewhere.
You should have been a salesman father!
In a way, I am.
It seems Mr Dobson, like the poor, is always with us.
When I was a child I was as stuffed with religion as a Strasborg goose with grain. I have no appetite left.
When you were a child you understood as a child, you thought as a child. But now you have become a man and have not put away childish things.
I gambled the cross for the soul of Flambeau. I like to think St Augustine would agree with me.
The acts we do for no evident reasons are sometimes the most rational.

We have something in common. All men do. That was the secret of the confessional you know. The more you learn about people, the more you learn about yourself. The more you learn about yourself, the more you know about other people.
I've paid for my collection. Not in the currency of shop keepers but in the currency of fear.
